Fair Play presents a system for making invisible labor visible and redistributing family responsibilities in an equitable way, so that one member of a couple isn‚Äôt stuck shouldering an unfair share of the work that goes into running a household. Using a gamified approach and providing step-by-step instructions, the book walks the initiating partner through how to introduce the Fair Play system, invite their partner to the table, get buy-in, and then play the game. The end result should be not only a more agreeable distribution of household tasks, but also greater clarity about who has ownership of which tasks and how both partners agree those tasks should be done. The author identifies 100 responsibilities couples with children typically have to keep up with and invites couples to customize their own unique ‚Äúdeck‚Äù of responsibilities by whittling that number down based on their family‚Äôs unique needs and values. Then, before the tasks are even divided, the Fair Play system asks couples to consider two things: 1) What is an agreed upon ‚Äúminimum standard‚Äù for each task‚Äôs completion? (emphasis on ‚Äúagreed upon‚Äù) and 2) What is actually required to ‚ÄúCPE‚Äù each task: In other words, what is does it take not only to ‚ÄúExecute‚Äù each task, but to shoulder the mental workload for each task, in the form of ‚ÄúConceptualization‚Äù and ‚ÄúPlanning.‚Äù According to Fair Play, if one member of a couple is going to own a task, fully and completely, they need to be responsible for all of these steps, without coaching or reminders; only then can the other partner truly remove that task from their mental To Do list.After these preliminary steps are completed, then the couple can decide how they want to divvy up the responsibilities. The goal isn‚Äôt necessarily to split the tasks 50/50, but each couple is supposed to come to an agreement about how they want to divide things up, based on both people‚Äôs availability, competency, and preferences. The system also includes steps for ongoing maintenance (i.e. routinely checking in with each other about how the system is working and ‚Äúre-dealing‚Äù cards as needed) and stresses the importance of including "tasks" for emotional wellbeing, such as social time and self care. I can‚Äôt give a critique of Fair Play in action, because my husband and I haven‚Äôt used the system yet; however, I will say that I appreciated the topic and liked the book. Even though I don‚Äôt have children and my partner shares responsibility for many of the daily chores (e.g. laundry and dishes), I still find myself being mentally exhausted from all the behind-the-scenes work that it takes to gets things accomplished in our home: Work that I‚Äôm primarily responsible for. Sure, my husband will go buy dog treats when we need them, but who notices when the treats are low, makes the request, tells him what brand we buy, and texts him a photo of the bag? Yes, we send out holiday cards ‚Äúfrom the two of us,‚Äù but who actually takes the photos, gets the cards printed, keeps the address book up-to-date, and addresses and stamps all the envelopes? Multiply this by countless tasks, and you can see how one person in a relationship quickly becomes burned out, tired, and resentful. What I liked most about the book is that it offered an actual system to address discrepancies in household labor, rather than just talking about the problem. As someone who likes rules, games, and systems, the Fair Play approach really spoke to me‚Äîand regardless of whether we adopt the system in my home or not, reading the book definitely got me thinking about equity in our home and motivated me to start a conversation with my partner about our household responsibilities. Because I like visual, tangible things, I also embraced the opportunity to DIY a homemade version of the Fair Play task cards, which my husband and I looked at together over glasses of wine, creating our own 39-card deck. We have a date on the calendar to talk about some version of MSC and CPE for each card, and then we‚Äôll see where it goes from there. Some people might argue that couples can just ‚Äútalk about household responsibilities without needing a book and a complicated system‚Äù‚Äîand while that‚Äôs true, I found that being able to say, ‚ÄúHey, I read this thing and I wanted to talk to you about it,‚Äù went over much better in my relationship than saying, ‚ÄúHey, can we talk about chores?‚Äù I also liked the way the author focused on mutual benefits from using the system, several of which I mentioned to my partner (which I think increased his buy-in.) In terms of my experience with the book itself, I found the audio book (read by the author) to be engaging, and I enjoyed her use of storytelling to bring the concepts to life and make them memorable. Although the author says Fair Play can be used by all couples, one critique I have is that the language in the book (at least the version I listened to) wasn‚Äôt very inclusive of LGBTQA+ relationships: Cards were routinely referred to using gendered language, such as ‚ÄúAdult Friendships (her)‚Äù and ‚ÄúAdult Friendships (him),‚Äù when gender-neutral language would have sufficed (e.g. ‚ÄúAdult Friendships, Partner 1 and Partner 2.‚Äù) In addition, while the author interviewed a lot of couples and included a lot of real-life scenarios in her book, the examples seemed to focus primarily (exclusively?) on middle and upper class families. At the very least, I feel like the book should have included an acknowledgement of the system‚Äôs limitations and areas in need of further exploration.I'm giving the book 4 stars because I think the author tackled an important topic and presented a set of ideas that may work well for some couples. I don't think the system will necessarily work for everyone, but I'm eager to start trying out some of the system in my own family.

I appreciate this book because it helped me think about my home responsibilities over the years. I might have benefited more from it when I had small children. I use this space as a reading journal for myself, so beware, a lot of this review is more about me than the book.I've been married to the same man for almost 33 years and all my children are adults. I also had that time when my daughter was still in the school system. There were years in between that were really tough when I should have spoken up for that privilege.I learned years ago that a helper is never in the way and never does it the wrong way. If you think otherwise, people don't want to help anymore. I learned to show a lot of gratitude for every single thing. I learned to ask nicely and make suggestions rather than to nag. Self pity is terrible and pointless. Building a loving relationship solves a lot of problems. This book's ideas are a bit of a short cut, but likely effective.My husband and I divide up care for our daughter. I have the morning routine; he has full responsibility for her bedtime routine. He helps her exercise and sits by her at meal times. There are no complicated systems or "cards" in place. We've just worked it out over years. We're good at consistency and habits. We're both reliable.So much pain could be avoided if we communicated everything and didn't let little things bother us. I like that the author shows that if a household duty isn't really important to us, we don't have to do it. Throughout our married life, it has really helped to keep expectations and demands low. At the same time, communicating what really matters is imperative.In this book, I particularly like the concept of "CPE" which is conceptualizing, planning, and executing a job from start to finish. That's new to me. The idea of only one person holding a responsibility through the entire conception, planning, and execution makes sense. That way things don't fall through the cracks. We had a situation just yesterday that might have been simpler and less troubling had one of us held the whole responsibility. One of our cars broke down and had to be towed to a dealer to get fixed. He called AAA and the car dealership. I met the tow truck. Usually, my husband deals with car issues, but this car was used by our children and doesn't really matter too much to either of us. Neither of us bothered to make sure the car arrived at the dealership nor checked up on it after its appointment. It wasn't until the dealership was closed that it occurred to me we hadn't heard a word about the car. Did it really make it there and get seen? We called, but realized the best solution was to drive out to the dealership to see it with our own eyes. It was there. It had a tag on the rear view mirror that proved it had been seen. It really wasn't a big deal, but the not-knowing part did cause me to panic a little. We ultimately shared the whole responsibility and solved it together. But maybe if one of us had full responsibility the stress of not knowing if the car was really there might have been avoided. I read this book because a psychologist on Instagram who I occasionally follow highly recommended it. I'm glad I read the book. I'm not sure I'd recommend to it my young-mom-married daughters, but I might. I think there is value in figuring things out without so many rules and gizmos. This is a title that was much talked about in 2019 (especially in the wake of Reese picking it for her book club), so when I saw it on the list of audiobooks I could check out from the library, I thought, "Well, why not?" The elements I took objection to in the book are covered in other reviews here on GoodReads, but I'll add that Eve's term "unicorn space" (to define the time partners gift one another to chase their passions) nearly drove me up the wall! There's nothing more deflating than when I go to put a five star book into Goodreads and then see that the average rating is 3.42. Yikes. For me the book has value for the idea alone of sitting down with my partner and talking about how labor is divided and doing it on a regular basis. Conceptualizing and planning are big responsibilities/burdens and I love the idea of pairing them with execution. I loved the terms the author came up with. I thought unicorn space was cute. I loved RATS-Random Assignments of Tasks. Of course, I appreciated CPE. The game player in me appreciated how the author treated this system like a game. I've seen this book criticized in Amazon reviews for "brow-beating" men. For the most part, I have to agree. The kicker is that I value all of the values of this book. All of them. These are real strategies that could empower couples to make the home more efficient. However, for men who value these values, the problem isn't explaining the values, nor is the solution dozens of anecdotes of men failing. The problem is often communication. When two parents are both working to make it work, the communication strategies used to discuss household labor are paramount. Since both parents are overworked and over-tired, a conversation about unequal divisions of labor will‚Äîof course‚Äîbe a tough topic without carefully crafted communication. The solution is more than a game.If you choose to read the book, be sure to live by‚Äîreally intentionally live by‚Äîthe marked "Caution!" notes. These easy-to-skip, half-page breaks in the author's condescension of all men are important for making sure that couples don't further entrench their resentment for each other.

3.75 starsThis book has a lot of strengths, and I love that it offers an interesting solution instead of just complaining about the gender gap in the parenting and domestic sphere, but it is lacking in a couple of ways. There are a few examples where it just seems like Rodsky got her way--she and her husband disagreed about how often to take the trash out (his job), and he ended up just doing it every evening like she wanted. Theoretically they discussed it together and agreed on a "minimum standard of care," but that isn't mentioned. At the end, one of their children wants to start a new activity and Rodsky's husband takes it on willingly--what if this wasn't the case and neither of them wanted to do it?Her descriptions of what personality type you are and who you are married to were very specific and reductive. None of the personality types fit me--the only one for working full time was "Superwoman," who does it all and handles it all (DEFINITELY not me); there were two categories for part-time working mothers and one for stay-at-home moms, and even the descriptions beyond the jobs didn't fit me. It just struck me as very odd. I also think some of the cards are very specific and some are extremely broad. I think each family will have to create some of their own due to their own life circumstances. Rodsky is writing the book from her current life perspective with kids all above age four; of course she remembers the younger years, but there are particulars for everyone's circumstances that differ. Even with childcare--there are different tasks depending on whether you have a nanny or daycare, and daycare policies and procedures (such as whether or not they serve food). Rodsky has done a lot of the legwork but I think we'll need to do a little more work with the cards so they reflect the tasks of our lives. I really enjoyed the perspective of a mediator, and I think terms and questions from that field like "Minimum Standard of Care" and "what would a reasonable person do or expect?" are extremely helpful. CPE, or "conceive, plan, execute," makes the book a worthy read on its own. Although with the cards, I understand the arguments for only one person being the CPE person for a particular card, and yet--that seems like a lot of work for a lot of the cards. I know they can be re-dealt and some often need to, but still. I am interested to try the game, with some tweaks for our family.

This book was essentially an application of business-style approaches to division of domestic labor. The author, Eve Rodsky, advocates that partners should divvy up types of tasks and ensure that one partner takes full responsibility for this task for at least a week at a time. Rodsky emphasizes that tasks involves conception, planning, and execution, and must adhere to a mutually-agreed upon minimum standard. I liked the acknowledgement that the conception and planning portions of tasks often fall, unnoticed, on women, and that giving full ownership to a specific partner is a useful way to decrease arguments. I also appreciated her acknowledgement that each person's time is equally useful, her encouragement of partners to add meaning to their lives through their "unicorn space" and the idea of establishing a minimum standard for completing tasks. With that being said, I didn't love the cutesy language/imagery and found myself struggling to buy into the idea of division of labor as a card game. I also struggled to situate myself or my relationship into the relationship structures highlighted in this book. This was clearly written for upper-middle class, white, cisgender, straight women, in families in which the man is the primary breadwinner and the woman is responsible for the majority of tasks related to children and home. In short, I found this book to be semi-useful but irritating in its lack of scope and narrow intended audience.

A few preliminary notes: If you are not married, don't read this book. If you don't have kids, proceed with caution. This book is entirely meant for families where there is tension around the time and effort spent on household tasks vs. careers vs. hobbies, etc. A huge part of that tension arises when children are in the picture and mothers become the default (or what she calls "she-fault") full-time Manager of Home and Offspring with little to no meaningful contribution from their husbands beyond the role of "primary breadwinner."Inspired by her own sense of complete dissatisfaction and frustration with the division of labor in her home, Eve Rodsky has developed a "game" where couples can determine a more equitable (fair, but not equal) way to manage their home life that will also enable them to free up time and mental space to pursue self-care, health, and passions/hobbies (what Rodsky terms "Unicorn Space"). She tackles the (sometimes inadvertent) sexism in so many marital relationships that results in husbands and wives spending their time so differently - in an extremely unreasonable and frankly unfair way. The end result is that when we respect our spouses and respect the inherent value in each other's time, we are able to develop a much more healthy family dynamic.The greatest objections I have heard to this book (besides objections from people who aren't the target audience) are that the book is man-hating or ultra-feminist, and that it degrades a "traditional" gender role. These objections must coming from people who haven't read the book because Rodsky's ultimate goal is always a happy and successful marriage, which is impossible if one or both parties are struggling with resentment. Content and joyful people create joyful marriages. Men, while typically more at fault when it comes to abdication of home responsibilities, are not solely blamed for any conflict, and women are encouraged to reject a blame game in favor of finding solutions. This book is not solely meant for families where both spouses work outside the home. Resentment and unfairness can still be present when one parent stays at home. Regardless of work status, Rodsky's goal is always an amenable solution to both parties in the marriage. A win-win is what we want, not a winner and a loser. Respect and trust are mutually beneficial and need to be mutually sought and practiced.I have not implemented the specific "game" in my own marriage, and honestly I think it would be difficult to do in a military marriage when the active duty member is absent for large amounts of time (perhaps we need a "Fair Play for Military Couples"?? Eve, consider this my official request!). But as far as principles go, and understanding the hurt and resentment many women feel while still wanting to maintain and develop a healthy marriage, Eve Rodsky really knocks the ball out of the park.
